paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory tumor state that improves sensitivity to immune checkpoint blockade (anti-PD-L1)?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Murine tumor models treated with intratumoral mRNA vaccine in combination with anti-PD-L1, pooled across repeat experiments to assess anti-tumor efficacy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (single agents/vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched murine controls including vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle arms pooled across experiments to benchmark baseline activity and specificity of effects.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status for outcome comparison.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination, used for survival comparison under ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination, serving as the comparator group for survival under ICI treatment.

major_limitations: Human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
